translated: The Exalted One’s Exclamations
With Upasena
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: Once, the Exalted One was staying at Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, at the Squirrels’ Feeding Ground.

original: Atha kho āyasmato upasenassa vaṅgantaputtassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmataḥ upasenassa vaṅganta puttassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evam cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, as the venerable Upasena Vaṅgantaputta was meditating in private, this train of thought arose in his mind:

analyzed: lābhāḥ vata me su laddham vata me
translated: “How fortunate for me, how very fortunate for me,

original: satthā ca me bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho;
analyzed: satthā ca me bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: that my teacher is the Exalted One, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One;

original: svākkhāte camhi dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito;
analyzed: su ākkhāte dhamma vinaye agārasmaā anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: that I have gone forth from the home into homelessness in the well-proclaimed Dhamma and Discipline;

analyzed: sabrahmacārino ca me sīlavantaḥ kalyāṇa dhammā
translated: that my companions in the holy life are virtuous and of good character;
that I have fulfilled the precepts;
that my mind is well concentrated and one-pointed;
that I am an Arahant, free from cankers;
that I am one of great power and great majesty.
My life has been blessed, and my death will be blessed.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato upasenassa vaṅgantaputtassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā āyasmataḥ upasenassa vaṅganta puttassa cetasā cetaḥ upari vitakka maññāya tāyam velāyam imam udānaṃ udānesi
translated: Then, the Exalted One, knowing with his mind the train of thought in the mind of the venerable Upasena Vaṅgantaputta, on that occasion, uttered this inspired utterance:
“He whose life does not shine forth,
He does not grieve at the time of death;
He is a hero who has seen the state,

analyzed: soka majjhe na socati  ucchinna bhava taṇhassa  santacittassa bhikkhuno
translated: and does not grieve in the midst of grief.🔽For the monk whose craving has been cut off,
whose mind is peaceful and content,🔽The round of birth is ended:
There is no continuation of existence.”
The ninth.
